title: Marriage certificate and ad for lost kids- support

content.description:
Source 1Marriage Certificate with Tintypes of Augustus L. Johnson and Malinda Murphy, 1874
Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of Louis Moran and Douglas Van Dine 

Source 2
“WANTED.
Information of the present whereabouts of my two children Albert and Margaret Carpenter, who were sold away from me in the town of Madison Court House, Va., and taken by slave-traders to the Cotton States, several years before the breaking out of the late rebellion. 
At the time the boy was only nine and the girl eight years of age. I was told that one Dick Mulhundro sold my daughter to a Georgian planter. I never knew what became of my son; I trust in God that this notice may in some way restore these dear ones to my arms again. A letter addressed to me in the care of my son William Stewart, Hamilton, Ohio would reach my hands by my last marriage. My name was changed to Lucinda Keys, Hamilton Ohio.”
Source: Advertisement placed by Lucinda Keys in The Christian Recorder, a periodical published by the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church,  1877.
content.question: Which of the following pieces of evidence best supports the claim that the Freedmen’s Bureau assisted formerly enslaved people’s transition into United States citizens?

choices.label: They promoted political engagement by supporting Jim Crow policies in Southern states.
They strengthened families with the introduction of the tradition of “jumping the broom.”
They facilitated the economic independence of freed people by encouraging sharecropping.
They worked to educate formally enslaved people by establishing schools in the South.

content.answer: They worked to educate formally enslaved people by establishing schools in the South.
